<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 118, 379, 142]]<|/det|>
# Cambridge IGCSE™  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 170, 183, 187]]<|/det|>
## PHYSICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 194, 368, 210]]<|/det|>
Paper 2 Multiple Choice (Extended)  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[782, 170, 905, 186]]<|/det|>
0625/21  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[782, 194, 905, 210]]<|/det|>
May/June 2020  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[814, 217, 905, 231]]<|/det|>
45 minutes  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 247, 507, 263]]<|/det|>
You must answer on the multiple choice answer sheet.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 277, 437, 293]]<|/det|>
You will need: Multiple choice answer sheet  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[215, 291, 539, 320]]<|/det|>
Soft clean eraser Soft pencil (type B or HB is recommended)  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 337, 228, 352]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 353, 910, 522]]<|/det|>
INSTRUCTIONS- There are forty questions on this paper. Answer all questions.- For each question there are four possible answers A, B, C and D. Choose the one you consider correct and record your choice in soft pencil on the multiple choice answer sheet.- Follow the instructions on the multiple choice answer sheet.- Write in soft pencil.- Write your name, centre number and candidate number on the multiple choice answer sheet in the spaces provided unless this has been done for you.- Do not use correction fluid.- Do not write on any bar codes.- You may use a calculator.- Take the weight of \(1.0 \text{kg}\) to be \(10 \text{N}\) (acceleration of free fall \(= 10 \text{m/s}^2\)).  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 549, 220, 564]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 565, 806, 613]]<|/det|>
INFORMATION- The total mark for this paper is 40.- Each correct answer will score one mark. A mark will not be deducted for a wrong answer.- Any rough working should be done on this question paper.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 97, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 72, 556, 91]]<|/det|>
A pendulum makes 50 complete swings in 2 min 40 s.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 102, 494, 120]]<|/det|>
What is the time period for 1 complete swing?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 129, 134, 147]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 129, 195, 147]]<|/det|>
1.6s

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[287, 129, 308, 147]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[313, 129, 361, 147]]<|/det|>
3.2s

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[447, 129, 468, 147]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[470, 129, 479, 147]]<|/det|>
4.8s

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[615, 129, 636, 147]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[651, 129, 673, 147]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 175, 97, 194]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 175, 636, 194]]<|/det|>
A student investigates the motion of a ball rolling down a slope.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 205, 625, 223]]<|/det|>
The diagram shows the speed \(v\) of the ball at different times \(t\).

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[175, 233, 819, 393]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 406, 529, 426]]<|/det|>
Which statement describes the motion of the ball?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 435, 133, 454]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 435, 421, 454]]<|/det|>
The acceleration is not constant.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 462, 133, 481]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 462, 390, 481]]<|/det|>
The acceleration is negative.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 488, 133, 507]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 488, 361, 507]]<|/det|>
The speed is decreasing.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 515, 133, 533]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 515, 351, 533]]<|/det|>
The velocity is constant.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 559, 97, 577]]<|/det|>
<label>3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 559, 504, 577]]<|/det|>
Which statement about acceleration is correct?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 587, 133, 605]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 587, 539, 605]]<|/det|>
It is related to the changing speed of an object.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 613, 133, 631]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 613, 554, 631]]<|/det|>
It is the distance an object travels in one second.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 640, 131, 658]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 640, 816, 658]]<|/det|>
It is the force acting on an object divided by the distance it travels in one second.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 665, 133, 683]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 665, 650, 683]]<|/det|>
It is the force acting on an object when it is near to the Earth.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 708, 97, 727]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 708, 779, 727]]<|/det|>
Which statement correctly describes the effects of placing a heavy load in a car?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 737, 133, 755]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 737, 695, 755]]<|/det|>
It is easier to accelerate the car and easier to bring the car to rest.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 764, 133, 782]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 764, 744, 782]]<|/det|>
It is easier to accelerate the car but more difficult to bring the car to rest.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 790, 133, 809]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 790, 804, 809]]<|/det|>
It is more difficult to accelerate the car and more difficult to bring the car to rest.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 816, 133, 834]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 816, 744, 834]]<|/det|>
It is more difficult to accelerate the car but easier to bring the car to rest.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 72, 109, 88]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 702, 89]]<|/det|> Water in a beaker evaporates when left on a bench for a period of time. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 102, 656, 120]]<|/det|> Which three factors all affect the rate of evaporation of the water? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 131, 134, 148]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 131, 472, 148]]<|/det|> wind speed, surface area, temperature <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 157, 134, 175]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 157, 430, 175]]<|/det|> wind speed, temperature, volume <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 184, 134, 201]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 183, 432, 201]]<|/det|> wind speed, surface area, volume <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 210, 134, 227]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 210, 440, 227]]<|/det|> surface area, temperature, volume <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 254, 106, 272]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 254, 430, 272]]<|/det|> A solid is heated causing it to expand. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 284, 598, 301]]<|/det|> What effect does this have on its mass and on its density? <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 312, 520, 440]]<|/det|>
massdensity

Dstays constantstays constant
<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 467, 106, 485]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 467, 808, 485]]<|/det|> The diagrams show four blocks of steel. The blocks are all drawn to the same scale. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 498, 609, 516]]<|/det|> The same quantity of thermal energy is given to each block. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 528, 551, 546]]<|/det|> Which block shows the greatest rise in temperature? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[173, 559, 195, 577]]<|/det|> <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[136, 587, 863, 688]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 714, 106, 733]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 714, 616, 733]]<|/det|> Why are metals better thermal conductors than other solids? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 744, 134, 761]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 744, 650, 761]]<|/det|> Metals contain free electrons which help transfer the energy. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 770, 134, 787]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 770, 500, 787]]<|/det|> Molecules in metals are in fixed positions. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 797, 134, 814]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 797, 460, 814]]<|/det|> Molecules in metals can move freely. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 823, 134, 841]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 823, 645, 841]]<|/det|> Molecules in metals vibrate faster than those in other solids.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 504, 106, 522]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 504, 348, 522]]<|/det|> Which statement is correct? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 533, 134, 551]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 533, 920, 567]]<|/det|> The speed of light in glass is equal to the speed of light in a vacuum multiplied by the refractive index of glass. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 574, 131, 593]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 574, 920, 609]]<|/det|> The incident angle of a light ray at an air-glass surface is the angle between the ray and the glass surface. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 618, 131, 636]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 617, 876, 644]]<|/det|> The sine of the critical angle at an air-glass surface is equal to \(\frac{1}{\text{refractive index of glass}}.\) <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 653, 133, 670]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 653, 920, 686]]<|/det|> The angle of refraction for light passing through an air-glass surface is proportional to the angle of incidence at that surface.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 106, 89]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 920, 106]]<|/det|> A \(100\%\) efficient transformer converts a \(240\mathrm{V}\) input voltage to a \(12\mathrm{V}\) output voltage. One of the bulbs fails. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 147, 524, 165]]<|/det|> How does the current in the primary coil change? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 175, 138, 193]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 175, 341, 193]]<|/det|> It decreases by 0.30 A. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 202, 136, 220]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 202, 351, 220]]<|/det|> It decreases by 0.015 A. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 228, 134, 246]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 228, 336, 246]]<|/det|> It increases by 0.15 A. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 254, 134, 272]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 254, 336, 272]]<|/det|> It remains unchanged. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 299, 106, 317]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 297, 920, 331]]<|/det|> Cables transmit electrical power from the output of the transformer at a power station to the input of the transformer at a substation. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[203, 339, 789, 457]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 469, 728, 488]]<|/det|> The power at the output of the transformer at the power station is 400 MW. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 500, 848, 518]]<|/det|> Which situation delivers the most power to the input of the transformer at the substation? <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 528, 598, 689]]<|/det|>
potential difference at power station transformer output/kVdiameter of cables
A200large
B200small
C400large
D400small

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 106, 88]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 71, 920, 106]]<|/det|> Uranium-235 is a radioactive isotope. It undergoes a chain of decays and eventually forms the stable isotope lead-207. These two isotopes are represented as shown. <|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[366, 121, 631, 152]]<|/det|> \[^{235}_{92}\mathrm{U}\qquad \qquad^{207}_{82}\mathrm{Pb}\] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 168, 920, 202]]<|/det|> During this chain of decay, how many protons and how many neutrons are lost from a single nucleus of uranium-235 to form a single nucleus of lead-207? <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 212, 416, 342]]<|/det|>
protonsneutrons
A1018
B1028
C1810
D2810
<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 368, 104, 387]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 368, 510, 388]]<|/det|> A radioactive material has a half-life of 20 days. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 400, 541, 419]]<|/det|> A sample of the material contains \(8.0 \times 10^{10}\) atoms. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 429, 566, 448]]<|/det|> How many atomic nuclei have decayed after 60 days? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 459, 133, 477]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 459, 240, 477]]<|/det|> \(1.0 \times 10^{10}\) <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[280, 459, 300, 477]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[313, 459, 403, 477]]<|/det|> \(4.0 \times 10^{10}\) <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[445, 459, 465, 477]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[475, 459, 520, 477]]<|/det|> \(6.0 \times 10^{10}\) <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[616, 459, 636, 477]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[640, 459, 739, 477]]<|/det|> \(7.0 \times 10^{10}\) <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 504, 106, 523]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 504, 922, 539]]<|/det|> A thin sheet of paper is placed between a radioactive source and a radiation detector. The count rate falls to a very low reading. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[316, 549, 680, 667]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 682, 633, 701]]<|/det|> From this result, which type of radiation is the source emitting? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 712, 134, 730]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 712, 243, 730]]<|/det|> \(\alpha\) -particles <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 740, 134, 757]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 740, 241, 757]]<|/det|> \(\beta\) -particles <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 767, 134, 785]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 767, 205, 785]]<|/det|> \(\gamma\) -rays <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 794, 134, 812]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 794, 210, 812]]<|/det|> X-rays

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 104, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>40</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 811, 91]]<|/det|>
\(\alpha\) -particles, \(\beta\) -particles and \(\gamma\) -rays are emitted by radioactive nuclei when they decay.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 102, 564, 120]]<|/det|>
Which emissions can be deflected by an electric field?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 133, 134, 151]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 133, 408, 151]]<|/det|>
\(\alpha\) -particles and \(\beta\) -particles only

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 160, 134, 178]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 160, 371, 178]]<|/det|>
\(\beta\) -particles and \(\gamma\) -rays only

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 188, 133, 206]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 188, 371, 205]]<|/det|>
\(\gamma\) -rays and \(\alpha\) -particles only

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 215, 133, 233]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 215, 428, 232]]<|/det|>
\(\alpha\) -particles, \(\beta\) -particles and \(\gamma\) -rays
